title: Fix wheel events; fixes #1048 #1047.
body:
Some time ago the hidden div scroll trick stopped working. But, this went nearly
unnoticed because most browsers are fairly well behaved since WebKit fixed bug
https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=40441 back in June 2010. All that
remained broken was Firefox, who adopted the newer W3C "wheel" event standard.
This commit removes the old div hack, and does better support detection to
determine the most standards-based approach to listening for wheel events.

title: Fix a couple of edge cases.
body: I think I prefer your approach as it seems easier to understand.  These were the only cases that I managed to break it on. :)

title: Increase biasing for Firefox's mousewheel events.
body:
Based on testing (Mac, MBP, mouse wheel), Firefox consistently never
reports higher than -1 for 'single scroll events'.

Chart: https://gist.github.com/4692169

Other things of concern:
- The system of re-dispatching mousewheel events to a hidden div does
  not appear to be active on Safari/Chrome/Firefox - fails with a DOM
  Exception in all on my machine.

title: Fix rounded formatting for 9×10ⁿ.
body: Fixes #1042.

title: jsdom globals deleted when loading as node module
body:
This was failing:

`var d3 = require('d3');
d3.select("body").append("div"); //append fails because window.document is undefined`

The loops in index.js are trying to prevent global conflicts and/or keep multiple calls to require('d3') from being destructive? If so it should be safe to just delete the `delete global[g]` line?

title: Return ambiguous, rather than undefined, centroid.
body: This is a fix for #1039, and related to #1037 #1011.

title: Ability to append via function
body: Looks like this functionality was in the plans according to the todos so I have implemented it. :rabbit2:

title: Allow type conversion in dsv.parse
body:
This is a stab at addressing #387, by adding an optional `types` argument to `dsv.parse`, which can either be an array or an object depending on whether the functions in `types` should be applied by position or name. (Although if you want to do the former, it seems better to just use `dsv.parseRows` directly.)

Problems:
1. `dsv.parse` was optimized in 2358fd0fb43d74cb72ddc4dd2218ab9153d0af02; this makes it slower again, even when the type conversion isn't used. I have created a [basic benchmark](https://gist.github.com/02033970558429c73626) for the behaviour using this function before optimization, after optimization, and after this change.
2. The interface may not be ideal. For numbers, I have been using `parseInt` and `parseFloat`, which could be wrapped as something like `d3.csv.int`, but then that's no shorter. For dates and times, `d3.time.format` already seems perfect to me.
3. As a corollary, because this accepts functions, it isn't restricted to just converting types. That seems like a duplication of effort, given that this is adding another layer of indirection: it calls another function from within `o`, which in turn calls the functions passed in `types`, and the only reason for not using `dsv.parseRows` is convenience. It's also possible for people to do unexpected things with it.
4. There is no type inference, which is mentioned in passing in the original issue.

title: Add qualitative schemes to colorbrewer.js and colorbrewer.css
body:
Not sure if this was intentional or not, but I tend to favor using the Set1 color scheme for different colors that are qualitative (see http://colorbrewer2.org). It would be good to incorporate the other qualitative schemes as well, including 'Accent', 'Dark2', 'Paired', 'Pastel1', 'Pastel2', 'Set1', 'Set2', and 'Set3'. Is there a reason why these were omitted from the lib package?

I'm happy to add so long as this wasn't an intentional omission.

title: fix a typo
body: I spotted a typo in the definition of the local variable d3_ease_mode. This is just a single commit fixing that.

title: Move tick class to the g element. Fixes #1016.
Export d3_identity function on d3 object
body:
The d3 core defines an identity function but does not make it available to the user. This simply adds it to the d3 object as d3.identity so the user can use it as well.

This simplifies nested data (myNode.data(d3.identity)...) and makes code more readable/

title: Optimise d3.geo.area.
body:
This incorporates two enhancements:
1. A simpler formulation for the area of a spherical triangle with one
   vertex at the south pole.
2. Instead of calling atan2 for every point, we use the identity:
    ∑ arg(z) = arg(∏ z),
   where z is a complex number, and only call atan2 once for each
   polygon, instead opting for a cheaper complex number multiplication
   for each point.

This is around 3x faster than the old implementation as measured by the
included benchmark.

title: Add area-weighted geographic polygon centroids.
body: This generalises the centre of mass formula given in J. E. Brock, The Inertia Tensor for a Spherical Triangle, J. Applied Mechanics 42, 239 (1975).

title: Add major & minor extent and step to graticule.
body: Fixes #1009.

title: Fix big with constant greatArc target.
body: The local variable `t` was masking the private field of the same name. The use of single-letter variables is preferred for smaller scopes.

title: Use (nw|ne|se|sw)-resize for intercardinal brush cursors
body:
`nwse-resize`, `nesw-resize`, `nwse-resize`, and `nesw-resize` don't display a custom cursor in Ubuntu Chromium 22, but works in Firefox. 

Cursor Test: http://jsfiddle.net/chriscoyier/wZ8K2/2/light/

title: Added d3.svg.transform, a way to construct SVG transform specifications
body:
Constructing SVG transform specifications currently involves some somewhat ugly string concatenation - e.g.

.attr("transform", function(d) { return "transform(" + d.x + "," + d.y + ") rotate(" + d.r + ")"; })

This diff adds d3.svg.transform, a builder for SVG transform strings.
We can replace the above code by the simpler code:

.attr("transform", function(d) { return d3.svg.transform().translateX(d.x).translateY(d.y).rotate(d.r); })

or

.attr("transform", function(d) { return d3.svg.transform().translate([d.x, d.y]).rotate(d.r); })

See tests for other examples.  Note that this does not implement the full SVG spec at http://www.w3.org/TR/SVG/coords.html#TransformAttribute,
only a subset determined by looking at how transforms are used in other D3 projects.

title: Fix duplicate keys
body: Fixes #997. The enter, update and exit selections are now initialized as fixed-length arrays rather than dynamically populated with nulls. If duplicate keys are used for either data or selected elements, only the first datum or element is considered and subsequent data or elements are ignored.

title: Fix for duplicate keys.
body: Fixes #997. The enter, update and exit selections are now initialized as fixed-length arrays rather than dynamically populated with nulls. If duplicate keys are used for either data or selected elements, only the first datum or element is considered and subsequent data or elements are ignored.

title: README.md: Point hyperlinks at github explicitly
body:
Using relative hyperlinks here results in some weirdness when the
readme is displayed on npmjs.org.

If this patch lands, I'd suggest also doing `npm publish -f` (or
just bump the version in package.json and `npm publish` un-forcefully.)

title: Added check for headless run (tests)
body: Tests were failing (not even starting) for me without this change. I'm still spotting many failures but maybe it is a problem due to my environment (node 0.8.15). An alternative would be to use a navigator emulator like https://github.com/coolaj86/node-navigator

title: RE: Issue 993 - fix to polygon area and centroid
body: ...addition, fixed incorrect tests of polygon area... the polygons were incorrectly marked as clockwise and counterclockwise.

title: Allow projection.invert to return null.
body: Previously this would throw errors.

title: Fix locale generation on Linux.
body:
The regexp was not unquoting the empty string surrounded by quotes.

Fixes #976.

title: fix zoom behavior for Android
body:
fixed for touch zoom in browser without d3.event.scale like firefox and chrome for Android.
Need some other test but work.
close #920

title: Fix d3.geo.circle.origin.
body: 3D rotations are not commutative, so we must perform an inverse rotation to move something from origin [0, 0] to [λ, φ].  Normally we are moving origin [λ, φ] to [0, 0].

title: In d3v3, geo.bounds stopped working for GeometryCollection within Feature
body:
`d3.geo.stream` incorrectly treated `GeometryCollection` as a higher-level object type, rather than a geometry type as specified in the GeoJSON spec. This caused bounds calculations to be incorrect on `Feature`/`FeatureCollection` objects that contained `GeometryCollection` geometries.

Patch adds a test for this case and corrects the handling of `GeometryCollection` in `d3.geo.stream` (and therefore `d3.geo.bounds`).
